### Why do aerial surveys?

Elephants and wildlife are often in remote and difficult terrain and the best way to count them is from the air. Aerial surveys provide vital information on their status, seasonal distribution and abundance. They improve our understanding of wildlife populations, which allows us to base our conservation action on solid scientific understanding and guide future research and monitoring, with an emphasis on evaluating the effectiveness of management policies.

EWB has conducted extensive aerial surveys to help determine elephant and wildlife numbers, their habitat needs and seasonal distribution. Since 2001, the EWB team has amassed over 4000 hours of aerial survey flying, counting wildlife in Angola, Botswana, Namibia and Zambia. EWB is meticulous and rigorous in conducting the most comprehensive aerial surveys, which are providing new and essential information on the population status of elephants and other threatened wildlife species.

### 2024 Technical Report: Population trends and conservation status of elephants in Botswana and the Kavango Zambezi Transfrontier Conservation Area

The 2024 peer-reviewed technical report, authored by Dr. Scott Schlossberg and Dr. Michael Chase, used data from aerial surveys between 2010 and 2022 to update the conservation status of elephants in Botswana, Angola, and the larger Kavango Zambezi Transfrontier Conservation Area (KAZA). KAZA includes portions of Botswana, Angola, Namibia, Zambia, and Zimbabwe and holds 228,000 elephants as of 2022. Download the report: [https://elephantswithoutborders.org/site/wp-content/uploads/Final-EWB-Ele-Pop-Trends-KAZA-report-Mar24.pdf](https://elephantswithoutborders.org/site/wp-content/uploads/Final-EWB-Ele-Pop-Trends-KAZA-report-Mar24.pdf)

### 2018 Northern Botswana Survey

The 2018 dry season census was a collaborative effort, jointly commissioned by the Botswana Department of Wildlife and National Parks (DWNP) and Elephants Without Borders (EWB), and is an essential follow-on to the success of EWB’s 2010 and 2014 aerial surveys. The highly experienced survey team included a Government of Botswana DWNP observer, and the newly released results reveal important changes in wildlife populations and a significant increase in elephant poaching. This is the first large-scale aerial survey of Botswana’s elephants and wildlife since 2014.

Elephants population estimate was 126,114. Statistically, since the 2014 survey the elephant population is considered unchanged. However, in Chobe NP, the long-term trend in elephant populations is downward, with estimates decreasing from 26,609 on the 2010 survey to 17,634 in 2014 to 15,404 in 2018. Bull populations decreased notably by 42% between 2014 and 2018. In the Okavango delta and surrounding areas elephant numbers have remained stable since 2010 at roughly 76,000.

During the survey, we observed that elephants are facing a growing poaching problem in northern Botswana. Our estimate revealed of over 400 elephants poached in Botswana within the last year, or more than one elephant poached per day. (download [Evidence of a Growing Elephant Poaching Problem in Botswana](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S096098221930675X), Current Biology 29, July 2019.)

North of Botswana, poachers have decimated elephant herds in both southeast Angola and southwest Zambia (download [Poaching and human encroachment reverse recovery of African savannah elephants in south-east Angola despite 14 years of peace](http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.371/journal.pone.0193469). Plos One, March 2018.)

Poaching in Botswana does not appear to have reached similar levels of severity at this time, but evidence suggests that this problem has now reached Botswana and is escalating.

An important positive result from this survey is that many populations of wildlife species have increased since 2010. We observed substantial increases in the number of lechwe, which increased to a record number from 57,637 in 2014 to 88,585, zebra have increased from 47,075 in 2014 to 59,592, wildebeest have nearly doubled in number from 8,945 to 16,485, and hippo increased from 8,680 to 12,660.

This recovery of wildlife in northern Botswana is an encouraging discovery, as the country’s economy relies heavily on wildlife tourism. Tourism is the country’s second largest foreign exchange earner after diamonds, contributing 2.1 billion (11.5%) to GDP, while employing nearly 80,000 people.

### 2014 Northern Botswana Survey

From July to October 2014, Elephants Without Borders (EWB) in collaboration with the Botswana Department of Wildlife and National Parks (DWNP) flew a 280-hour aerial survey over a 98,425 km2 area of northern Botswana, counting elephants and other wildlife. This survey was flown as part of the [Great Elephant Census (GEC)](https://elephantswithoutborders.org/projects/great-elephant-census/), which was funded by Mr. Paul G. Allen and his sister Jody.

The total elephant population estimate in northern Botswana was 129,939 ± 12,500 margin of error (95% confidence interval), making it the largest elephant population in Africa. The overall population estimate is little changed from the 2010 EWB estimate of 128,340, but noticeably concentration or densities of elephant herds in various areas had changed. Some areas such as Ngamiland (the Okavango delta,) Makgadikgadi & Nxai Pan National Parks showed an increase in numbers, however in Chobe National Park, elephant populations decreased to their lowest levels since the early 1990s and have been decreasing every year since 2006. Many of the changes in local elephant populations are likely due to movements of elephants between different parts of Botswana.

Other population estimates of note (for the entire region) include: zebra – 47841, buffalo 26712, giraffe – 9409, lechwe – 57000,  hippo – 8750 and impala – 72,272. While wildebeest, tsessebe and springbok continue their large population declines, ranging from 7-10% per year. Ostrich are declining by 9% annually throughout northern Botswana

### Chobe Forest Reserves Surveys

EWB flew consecutive seasonal surveys during both the wet and dry seasons between 2011 and 2013 over the Chobe District, a survey area of about 22560 km2 in extent, which included Chobe National Park (NP), Chobe Forest Reserve (FR), Kasane FR and Extension, Kazuma FR, Sibuyu FR and Maikaelelo FR, and surrounding Wildlife Management Areas.

Results revealed herbivore populations in the District appear to be stable. However, the extent of bush fires across large areas of the District, a major determinant in the health of the ecosystem, are concerning. Also, the level of deforestation and encroaching human activities for arable fields along the Northern Plains ecotone and Chobe FR ridge, which both fall within important wildlife corridors are destructive, and will impede wildlife movements and should be conserved. The allocation of arable fields in the middle of identified elephant pathways is hindering wildlife access to water, which will lead to an inevitable increase in human elephant conflict. While there is considerable development taking place within the District, EWB is determined to continually assist local, district and central government authorities to provide them with scientific data to ensure a positive relationship between people and wildlife co-existing in the region.

### 2010 Northern Botswana Survey

![surveys_northern_botswana_map](https://sp-ao.shortpixel.ai/client/to_webp,q_glossy,ret_img,w_580,h_414/https://elephantswithoutborders.org/site/wp-content/uploads/surveys_northern_botswana_map.jpg)During the 2010 dry season, a fixed-wing aerial survey of elephants and wildlife was flown over the core wildlife conservation areas of northern Botswana. The aerial survey took nearly 250 hours of flying time, a flight line total of 25,598 km, covering a total of 73,478 km2, which included the National Parks of Chobe, Makgadikgadi, Nxai Pan, Moremi Game Reserve, the Okavango Delta and the surrounding Wildlife Management Areas in the Ngamiland, Chobe and Central districts. Technically robust, the survey’s sampling intensity averaged 20% in comparison to 5% during previous surveys and is the first independent fixed-wing aerial survey to provide concession level estimates for wildlife populations in Botswana.

Between 1993 and 2004, the Botswana government had conducted eight systematic aerial surveys. EWB’s 2010 data allowed for a comparative analysis of wildlife distribution, abundance and trends over time. However, some of the results were unexpected and revealed that in 17 years, the populations of 11 animal species in the Okavango Delta specifically had plummeted by an average of 61 per cent, while elephant numbers across northern Botswana appeared to have stabilized, and in the Chobe district where the highest density of elephants occur, the majority of wildlife populations remained fairly stable or were increasing. These findings raised much concern, awareness, and some scepticism, however also stimulated action, on many levels, to ensure a better understanding of the drivers causing downward trends.

This study also verified the importance of continual monitoring and that conservation management requires a solid understanding of wildlife population dynamics and reliable estimates of population densities, while further research is required to ensure a healthy ecosystem.

### Kavango-Zambezi Transfrontier Area (KAZA TFCA) Surveys

In January 2003, at the end of almost 30 years of civil conflict in Angola, EWB flew the first systematic aerial survey, ever, to estimate elephant and wildlife numbers in southeast Angola. The survey area, Luiana Partial Reserve, was severely affected by the civil war. It is reported that 100,000 elephant were slaughtered for their ivory and meat to help fund the war. In this area, which was left with virtually no wildlife, EWB, together with Conservation International, was the first organization to record wildlife population returning to southeast Angola. EWB expanded their surveys to encompass the neighbouring protected area, Sioma Ngwezi National Park, in southwest Zambia, (the last estimates for elephants in this remote park were taken in 1969), and Namibia’s Caprivi Strip. These surveys provided the first comprehensive regional assessment on the status of elephant populations. Subsequently, aerial surveys were conducted each year, over 3 years, which provided data to undertake comparative analyses.

EWB’s data from these aerial surveys revealed that elephants were returning in growing numbers to southeast Angola. The 2005 survey data of the Caprivi Strip, suggests that elephant numbers increased by only 15%, since 1998, which, is considered a relatively small population increase over such a timeframe. However, in Sioma Ngwezi, elephant numbers appeared to have decreased from 1,212 in 2003 to 385 in 2005. In contrast, the three aerial surveys of Luiana Partial Reserve in southeast Angola indicated that elephant numbers were increasing rapidly and expanding their range, from 329 in January 2004, to 1827 in November 2005, to an estimate of 8000 in 2007. The end of the war in Angola appears to be providing the requisite security for elephants to return to their ancestral homeland.

### ![collaborations_map](https://sp-ao.shortpixel.ai/client/to_webp,q_glossy,ret_img,w_580,h_356/https://elephantswithoutborders.org/site/wp-content/uploads/collaborations_map.jpg)Okavango Panhandle Surveys

The Okavango Panhandle is considered a high human-elephant conflict (HEC) area in Botswana. In this troublesome conflict zone, elephants are trapped by the Caprivi border fence and northern buffalo fence. The impenetrable floodplains of the Okavango River restrict elephants moving west out of the region. Within this 8500sq km area, the only permanent water is in the Okavango River, where many settlements are located. During the dry season, elephant herds run a daily gauntlet through settlements to reach water in the Okavango River. How many elephant are trapped in this region? What is the population growth rate? What management options are there to help relieve this compression? To help answer these pertinent questions EWB collaborated with Anna Songhurst, a PhD student from the University of Botswana and Imperial College, London, studying HEC. Together we flew 2 aerial surveys. The first survey, conducted in August 2008, yielded an estimate of 9000 elephants trapped in the Okavango triangle. In July 2010, the second survey was conducted and the survey results estimated a staggering 14,000 elephants. ?EWB suggests that corridors be created to allow elephant to move out of this region. Corridors must be created along wildlife migration paths that meet up with the fence. Creating small gaps or openings in the fence will allow elephants to move into the Caprivi and Angola where elephant densities are low and relieve HEC along the Okavango River.

# Can very high resolution satellite imagery and artificial intelligence modernise wildlife surveys in Africa?

Connected Conservation Foundation joins Airbus Foundation, Northern Rangelands Trust, Madikwe Futures Company NPC, NTT Ltd and Microsoft to investigate.

* * *

**_Published 15 March 2024_**

The populations of African elephants and White and Black rhinos have fallen across Africa over the last 40 years. Wildlife surveys are essential for monitoring changes in population numbers and the movement of species across landscapes. They provide a valuable source of data to inform critical decisions on how best to conserve threatened species. Traditional survey methods in savannah landscapes use aerial counts completed by humans in a plane, but this can be costly, and labour-intensive, with variable results.

There is growing interest in using <1m high-resolution satellite imagery and artificial intelligence (AI) technologies to survey large mammals (over 1m in size) across vast and hard-to-reach areas.

The Connected Conservation Foundation led a cross-sector collaboration to explore if the use of these technologies can provide a practical and feasible method to reduce the time and cost of wildlife surveys in savannah environments.

A summary of the study findings can be found in this blog, but you can [download the full white paper here](https://services.global.ntt/-/media/ntt/global/insights-and-resources/white-papers/connected-conservation-white-paper---ai-and-satellite-imagery-in-wildlife-surveys.pdf).

![](https://connectedconservation.foundation/media/eojfomli/elephant-image2.jpg)

Our project aimed to compare the results of AI and human detections of species in 30 cm resolution satellite imagery, with on-the-ground sightings reported by field teams around the time of satellite pass over.

Additionally, as protected areas in savannah environments typically consist of both heterogenous (complex and non-uniform terrain and flora) and homogenous landscapes, (open areas with less background variation, i.e. around watering holes), our study sought to detect and classify large animals across both environments.

![](https://connectedconservation.foundation/media/uodpfoio/microsoftteams-image-10.png)

The practical study found that, although some results showed promise, significant challenges remain in using satellite imagery to survey species in savannah situations. The algorithm detection and visual human inspection of large animals in 30 cm resolution satellite imagery (incident angle <15°), did not give conservation managers the required level of accuracy in individually counting and classifying species, in comparison to on-the-ground sightings.

##### **Principle research findings included:**

- Both human inspection of this imagery and AI model analysis could not discern between different species of large mammals in certain situations, including:

\- When different species are interspersed together in the same area (elephants/rhinos, wildebeest/buffalo). For example, near watering holes.

\- When juvenile species are mixing with other adult species. For example, the difference between a juvenile elephant and an adult buffalo or rhino.

\- Additionally, when species such as elephants bunch close together, the shadows of several animals merge into one, resembling a ‘blob’, and it is difficult to count exact numbers.

- Cloud cover is a barrier to this survey method. During the study, on-the-ground field teams made many wildlife sightings at the approximate time of the satellite pass over. However, even on a 96% cloud-free day, vital ground sightings of Black rhinos were obscured by the only small cloud in the region. This resulted in priority sightings not being identified in satellite imagery, which was unsatisfactory to conservation managers.

- Lastly for the AI, there was a lack of animal sightings in the imagery to function as labelled training data. Instead, novel approaches to creating synthetic training data were explored. 3D imagery, and downsized drone imagery, as a representative of real sightings, were used to train the algorithms, with limited success.


**Ongoing research is needed to explore new species and situations where 30 cm satellite imagery can be of value.**

Specifically in homogenous landscapes or seascapes, where the objects of interest have a strong contrast to stand out from their background environment. Use cases could include monitoring colonies or herds of animals in hard-to-reach environments, where greater variability in counting accuracy can be tolerated and mixing between species groups is limited.

##### **Study approach**

Through [Airbus Foundation](https://www.airbus.com/en/sustainability/airbus-foundation) archived data and new satellite tasking from the Airbus satellites Pléiades and Pléiades Neo, our study endeavored to build synthetic training data and test the feasibility of three approaches for the detection and identification of animals in very high-resolution satellite images:

1. The human eye only, to find and classify different species in the images
2. Computer vision and open-source (pre-trained) neural network models
3. A combination of computer vision and a bespoke convolutional neural network model, trained on a set of synthetic animal images

Where possible, animal identifications were then compared with on-the-ground sightings reported by field teams around the time of satellite pass over.

##### **Methods**

For key taskings, field teams were tactfully positioned in the field to count sightings on the ground. Two areas in Madikwe were selected, targeting known areas of wildlife density, totalling 200 km2 of Madikwe Game Reserve. The capture was scheduled for 10:33 am South African Standard Time (SAST) on 2 March 2022, at an incident angle <15°. At the same time, three teams collected field data on wildlife positions between 10:30 am and 12:30 pm.

A similar process was taken for Sera Wildlife Sanctuary in collaboration with Northern Rangelands Trust’s GIS and Ranger teams. 100km2 of 30 cm Pleiades Neo imagery was captured, but only a smaller number of target species were sighted at the time (reasons outlined in the report) so the focus concentrated on Madikwe.

Field teams took different routes through Madikwe’s tasked areas (shown below), specifically near water points where wildlife (particularly elephants and rhinos) are frequently seen.

**![](https://connectedconservation.foundation/media/xvrn4vog/microsoftteams-image-18.png)**_Figure 2: Planned field team routes, Madikwe Game Reserve (map data: Google, Airbus/ Maxar Technologies)_ During this tasking, 57 animals were identified by field teams around the time of satellite pass over. These were plotted by location with grid references to an area approximately 500m x 500m, or where the vehicle spotting the animals was likely positioned when identification was made (see below).

![](https://connectedconservation.foundation/media/wobmttki/map-with-pins_v3-copy.jpg)

_Plotted field sightings locations, Madikwe Game Reserve_

Most of the relevant sightings were recorded between 10:44-11:40 am. Calculating the maximum speed of animal travel (kph), these animals were expected to be well within estimated km2 ranges around pins at 10:33 am (when the satellite passed), so are expected to be seen on the satellite imagery.

By sending out field conservationists at the time of capture across partner reserves, for some pins, the cloud-free 30 cm data offered the opportunity to compare direct elephant detections, between in-field sightings, and human eyeballing on 30 cm satellite imagery, alongside AI classifications.

The following three approaches were explored and compared with this ground-truthed data.

##### **Approach 1: The human eye only, to find and classify different species based on field-based expertise and insight**

Madikwe's conservation experts with substantial local field experience manually scanned the satellite imagery with the human eye and identified 110 large mammals across the 200 km2 Area of Interest (AOI). Conservation experts used their in-depth knowledge of the reserve and species behaviours in this landscape to record their understanding and classification of the sightings.

The below images were taken at a 1:100 scale from the 30 cm satellite image captured at the same time as the plotted sightings for the first satellite image above. Using field data, it was concluded that the bottom left image contains only rhinos, and the animals in the rest of the images are elephants. This example indicates how difficult it is to differentiate between rhinos and elephants in 30 cm imagery taken close to the nadir line (the point on the Earth’s surface directly below the satellite).

![](https://connectedconservation.foundation/media/mk1l4rzp/wildlife-sightings-collection-copy.jpg)

##### **Approach 2: Computer vision and open-source (pre-trained) neural network models, trained on a set of synthetic animal images taken from drones and down-sized**

Dimension Data Engineers identified three state-of-the-art object detector models as being best suited for rhino classification: RetinaNet (using the ResNet50 backbone), EfficientDet (EfficientNet backbone) and YOLOv5 (using the CSPDarkNet and a PANet neck).

For the purposes of rhino detection, no satellite training data was available for these endangered species. Object detection approaches require an incredibly large amount of training data to ensure that the model can reasonably learn differentiating features. Therefore, this approach developed a synthetic training data set. This involved cropping rhino images taken from varying resolution drone and aerial imagery into bounding boxes, then downsized to the resolution of the satellite sub-image in the training set, (10,000 training images across approaches).

When running these trained models on 30 cm satellite data of Madikwe Game Reserve, the accuracy of results for 30 cm was unsatisfactory due to the high number of false positives provided by the models. However, based on the spread of false positives compared to the synthetic ground truth, these off-the-shelf models could potentially provide a heatmap ‘where to look’ approach to potential detections. This may be a useful option for conservation managers. (see below on candidate for future exploration).

![](https://connectedconservation.foundation/media/zvckg4mg/synthetic-data.jpg)

##### **Approach 3: A combination of computer vision and a bespoke convolutional neural network model, trained on a set of synthetic 3D animal images**

For this approach, Dimension Data Engineers used open-sourced computer-generated imagery of the animals to create a synthetic data set to train a convolution neural network (CNN) model for animal classification. Samples are seen in 3D top-down, representing the outline and size of the animals, as seen from the nadir line. The images were downscaled to match the satellite imagery resolution and stitched into the satellite imagery.

![](https://connectedconservation.foundation/media/fped4h4d/microsoftteams-image-4.png)_Downscaled elephant sample (to actual size)_

##### **Challenges**

The biggest challenges uncovered through this investigation, include:

- **_Heterogeneous vs homogeneous environments_**

The complexity of dealing with heterogeneous environments opposes typical image processing methodologies. Complexity in an image is synonymous with ‘noise’ or random variation of brightness or colour, making it extremely difficult to isolate one region of interest from the background.

- **_Shadows_**

Shadows in remotely sensed imagery are produced by different objects, namely clouds, trees, boulders and mountains. These shadows have the potential to impact the accuracy of information extraction. For example, when elephants are bunched together, shadows and blobs can merge and field teams get different results from humans eyeballing the imagery, ground-truthed data and AI. In this 30 cm image, taken at a Dam in Madikwe, a group of elephants are under the trees with shadows. It is difficult to accurately count how many are in the yellow box. Human detection of this image identified five elephants, but this was debated by the field team, who sighted only four in the area.

![](https://connectedconservation.foundation/media/vmxlqzu2/microsoftteams-image-5.png)Additionally, when satellite images are captured at a higher incident angle, the shadows of the animal are more pronounced and play a more significant part in classification predictions. It is extremely challenging to provide enough synthetic training data for all shadow possibilities for each species. This project only focused on images captured close to the nadir line. Higher incident angles could be a future area of research.

- _**Time of satellite pass over**_

The orbit timings for the Pléiades Neo constellation of satellites were a major constraint for performing wildlife surveys in Kenya. Capture times for geographies nearer the equator fall around 11.30-12.30 pm local time in the heat of midday. African wildlife often ventures out into the open in the early morning to feed and drink, then retreat to the shade to avoid the heat of the midday sun. In our Kenyan study site, animals were often concealed by vegetation at the time of satellite acquisition. The project focus moved to the lower latitude in South Africa and Madikwe Game Reserve, where earlier tasking allowed for better conditions for wildlife sightings and approach testing.

- **_Cloud cover_**

When surveying such large areas, there is a high probability that some clouds will obscure important sightings, even on a largely cloud-free day.

![](https://connectedconservation.foundation/media/ofsmeo2w/image1-3.jpg)

The Madikwe captures were tasked on optimal days, with excellent visibility and clear skies, with the image recording under 5% cloud cover. For a critical tasking, of the 57 sightings captured by on-the-ground teams during pass over, one field-ranger sighting identified two rhinos at a known location. However, this sighting was concealed by the only cloud in the sky that morning. If this had been an annual wildlife survey, these two crucial sightings of a critically endangered species would have been missed.

##### **Results summary**

The project found both AI and human detection on satellite imagery present many opportunities for error and variable results.

Conservation teams at NRT and Madikwe Game Reserve, concluded the accuracy of both AI and human detection of species on 30 cm satellite imagery was not consistent enough in comparison to or to replace traditional (human-in-plane) wildlife survey techniques. Even when applying additional information on animal behaviours and known movements, field teams were unable to validate species classifications with satisfactory certainty for a wildlife survey.  Results for small areas of the homogenous landscape were more encouraging with classification accuracy more closely matching on-the-ground sightings. However as heterogeneous and homogenous landscapes were found interspersed across all CCF’s partner reserves, conservation managers needed satisfactory accuracy across both environments, to justify the investment in satellite image capture of these regions.

Only when aerial drone technologies enable image resolution beyond 30 cm to < 20 cm should these methods be pursued as a viable individual-wildlife-counting technique for mixed large mammals, in mixed (heterogeneous /homogeneous) savannah environments.

##### **A potential use-case for AI monitoring of wildlife in satellite imagery**

One notable outcome of this study is that rather than AI providing satisfactory individual counting and locations of animals, the techniques produced a heatmap style of potential sightings, acting as an indicator of ‘where to look’ for human-eyeballing validation within an image (see below). Scanning satellite imagery with the human eye is incredibly time-consuming and requires exceptional diligence, so consulting with an AI model to highlight areas of potential detection could be valuable. Field teams believe this may be useful for certain use cases, especially when locating (rather than individual animal counting) hard-to-find colonies or herds of certain species in remote areas.

![](https://connectedconservation.foundation/media/nrnnmodj/image-for-airbus-copy_v2-copy.jpg)

##### **What's next?**

Building on this work, collaborators now seek to identify the species and situations around the world where 50 cm and 30 cm resolution satellite imagery can be of value, especially in homogenous, hard-to-reach environments, where greater variability in accuracy can be tolerated.

Airbus Foundation and the Connected Conservation Foundation recently partnered to launch the [Satellites for Biodiversity Award](https://connectedconservation.foundation/grant-awards/ "Grants"), a program that will provide funding for projects and access to very high-resolution satellite data to monitor and manage threatened species and habitats. Where wildlife surveys are concerned, with a particular interest in homogeneous landscapes and seascapes, especially when the species of interest has a strong contrast to their background.

The application period for the award has now closed, and we are thrilled to have received so many applications. Winners will be announced in April – so stay tuned to find out who they are!

For more information, [click here](https://connectedconservation.foundation/news/new-award-to-advance-biodiversity-conservation-from-space/ "PRESS RELEASE: new award to advance biodiversity conservation from space").

##### **Collaboration and acknowledgements**

At Connected Conservation Foundation, we are proud to have led an innovative study into the feasibility of using artificial intelligence (AI) techniques and satellite images in wildlife surveys. This study could not be possible without the collaborative resources and skills of our partnerships, and we are truly thankful.

We are grateful for the generous donation of satellite imagery from Pléiades Neo, the new 30 cm-resolution optical constellation, from the [**Airbus Foundation**](https://www.airbus.com/en/sustainability/airbus-foundation). # Traveller wildlife surveys

## Our citizen science project: 85,859 surveys and counting

### Why we survey Africa's wildlife

Almost all of us here at Expert Africa are wildlife addicts: it's one of the reasons we love the continent. We also know that the vast majority of our travellers have more than just a passing interest in wildlife - and many are keen and knowledgeable on myriad creatures big and small.

Trying to understand and protect wildlife is paramount to us and many of our travellers; it's in our DNA. In 2018, we launched a project to better track the wildlife in the areas in which we specialise. To help us, we have been asking our travellers to record information about their sightings of some of Africa's key mammals.

Quantifying the sightings from various camps and parks across Africa is enabling us to build up a picture of the animal populations in East and Southern Africa. It will enable easier comparisons of the populations and, ultimately, will help us, and our partners on the ground, to better understand how these populations are changing over time.

It's still early days, but we have already had great interest in our data from wildlife researchers. We've shared our raw sightings data with hyena researchers and it has helped them to understand the population distributions better. We understand that it has even helped them to extend their distribution map for one species of hyena!

We hope that in time these wildlife insights will produce more tangible contributions to wildlife research and conservation awareness across many species and areas. Meanwhile, for now they will certainly help our team and our travellers to understand the chances of wildlife sightings in places that they plan to visit.

### How our wildlife survey works

Before travelling, all of our travellers receive a wildlife survey booklet tailored to their trip. We simply ask them to tally their 'sightings' of individual species seen from every camp at which they stay.

In this context, 'a sighting' means one occasion on which someone in the traveller's party saw one or more animals of one species. For example:

- Seeing a pride of five lionesses together would count as only 'one sighting'.
- The same pride seen later on the same activity would not count as a 'new sighting'.
- The same pride seen later on a different activity would count as a 'second sighting'.
- Two male lions seen separately from the pride, some distance away, would count as a 'separate sighting'.

When they return from their trip, we ask them to report this data to us as part of their wider feedback data on their trip. We're immensely grateful that the vast majority of our travellers do this - and the detailed results of this are now visible on our website.

We only include wildlife sightings data from travellers who make their arrangements with us; we don't accept any third-party data or information from anyone at any place which has not been part of one of our holidays.

### How we use this information on this website

We use this wildlife information on our website in a variety of ways, to try to make it clearer for travellers to see at a glance which species previous visitors have seen, and hence what the chances of seeing a particular animal are likely to be.

#### Wildlife sightings on our Review pages

On our individual camp review pages, like [Tafika Reviews](https://www.expertafrica.com/zambia/south-luangwa-national-park/tafika/reviews/1), we detail the individual sightings of the travellers who have kindly shared their experience with us.

Click on each animal in the row at the top for a summary of the sightings of this species at this camp. See the individual reviews below for the detail of exactly when each sighting report happened.

This data is the source of all of the other wildlife data that we deduce on our site: it's all grounded very firmly and precisely in what our travellers have reported to us. Nothing's added to this and nothing's taken away!

#### Wildlife sightings on our Wildlife pages

On our dedicated wildlife pages, we report the 'success' our travellers have had in seeing a particular species from individual camps and lodges.

For example, our [Wild dog in Africa](https://www.expertafrica.com/wildlife/wild-dog/africa) page reports the top camps in Africa for seeing wild dog, as measured by the % success.

To calculate this, we count time spent at each camp separately. We look at the number of our travellers who stayed at a camp where wild dog are known to occur and who reported their wildlife observations to us. It shows the percentage of these travellers who reported to us that they had had at least one sighting of wild dog during their stay.

For each of the top ten places, a graph and data summary is displayed beside the map. On a desktop computer, moving your mouse over the 'donut graph' will give you more understanding of the frequency of sightings at that location.

Where two camps have the same probability of success based on our reports, we'll rank the camp with the greater number of reports before the camp with fewer reports - so higher up on the map sidebar. Currently we don't try to take the duration of our travellers' stay at each camp, or the time of year, into account in these statistics. We hope to look at including this information when we have a lot more wildlife information collated.

For camps that don't make it into the _Top 10_ for a particular species, more information is available for desktop computers if you click on the circle which marks the camp's location.

#### Wildlife on our Holiday pages

For each holiday on our website which includes elements of safari, we estimate the chances of our travellers seeing the various species. To do this, we assume that the likelihood of one of our travellers seeing a particular species in a future visit is the same as the 'success rate' that our previous travellers have had seeing that particular species at that lodge in the past.

For example, our [Caracal Self-drive Safari](https://www.expertafrica.com/namibia/trip/caracal-self-drive-safari) includes eight different places in Namibia. We take into account the average length of stay of our previous travellers at each location, and the length of the stays in the various locations of this holiday.

From this data, we can calculate the chances of a traveller seeing this species at least once if they take this particular holiday in the future. Looking at the results and knowing the areas and lodges and the sightings record at these, we're very happy that the chances that have been calculated are representative.

There are exceptions when, for example, very low numbers of observations at a particular lodge will skew the results (see 'pangolin' below), but in general these results seem very fair.

### The limitations of our wildlife data

We're delighted with the data that we have so far and the ways in which it can help our travellers, and some wildlife researchers, as they make decisions about what they do in Africa. Its strength and depth should improve greatly over the coming months and years as more of our travellers report their sightings to us.

Obvious limitations of our wildlife data include:

- Where there are low numbers of reports, the conclusions will seem unreasonable. For example, if only one person has been to a particular lodge, but they have recorded a sighting of a pangolin, then this lodge will show '100% success' for sightings of pangolins. Whilst this is true, it's clear that doesn't mean that our next traveller to this lodge can be certain of seeing a pangolin!
- We don't yet take account of the time of year of sightings - despite the fact that in some cases the time of year makes a massive difference to the quality and quantity of game-viewing in some areas. We hope to be able to do this when we have a lot more data.
- Currently most of the conclusions of our data are drawn from the simple question: 'Did our travellers see this species whilst at this camp/lodge or not?' We make less use of the number of sightings, and in future we hope to use this information more, to make our conclusions richer and more detailed.

### Our selection of wildlife species

We currently survey 26 different species. This wasn't a very scientific selection; it was simply our choice. We selected the species that we believed would be the most interesting to record and those that would be of most interest to our travellers.

We know there are many omissions and, even just thinking of our own personal interests, we might have chosen many more - from aardwolves to waterbuck, not to mention some of the more conspicuous reptiles, amphibians and many magnificent birds. However, we restrained ourselves, mindful that we didn't want to make our traveller's reports too long or onerous.

So please accept our apologies if a particular species in which you have an interest isn't included here. We hope that in a few years, we may be able to widen the survey further.

However, in the meantime do call us to discuss any aspects of the wildlife that you'd like to understand more. We’ll almost certainly be able to help you - using our own first-hand experience, and the knowledge of our extensive network of wildlife guides in Africa - towards a wildlife safari in Africa that truly matches your interests.

## Abstract

Monitoring wildlife populations at scale is fraught with logistical and resource constraints. Despite this, estimating wildlife population state variables and vital rates remains crucial for science, and to assess conservation investment and effort. The veracity and transparency of results also helps prevent politicization of wildlife populations. In Uganda, robust estimates of carnivore population size are rare in the literature. To overcome a near two-decade long data gap we initiated a survey of African lions, leopards, and spotted hyenas with the Uganda Wildlife Authority across six important protected areas. Surveys were conducted within a spatial capture-recapture framework, the industry gold-standard for monitoring carnivore populations. For lions, we used unstructured spatial sampling protocols (in the form of vehicle-based searches), while for leopards, and spotted hyenas we deployed camera traps. Our protocols were designed to obtain unambiguous individual identification photographs. This large-scale effort involved data collection by >100 local conservation stakeholders (including lodge guides, trophy hunters, university students, and government rangers). Locally extinct in three areas, we show lion numbers are precariously low in two of three sites where they still occur (Queen Elizabeth abundance=39.72, Posterior standard deviation (PSD)=7.96; Kidepo Valley abundance=22.23, PSD=11.67). Murchison Falls was identified as Uganda’s lion stronghold with an estimate of ∼240 individuals (PSD=34) and average park-wide densities of 7.43 individuals/100 km2 (PSD=1.05). Leopard densities were highest in Lake Mburo and Murchison Falls. In Murchison they reach some of the highest densities in Africa (14.06 individuals/100 km2, PSD=2.65). Spotted hyena densities were high compared to lions (range=6.15–45.31 individuals/100 km2), except in Lake Mburo where densities were markedly lower (park abundance=23 individuals in 370 km2, PSD=5.26). Our work has critical policy implications, and forms the foundation of the new Strategic Action Plan for Large Carnivore Conservation in Uganda (2023–2033). It also illustrates how cutting-edge, transparent and collaborative science, implemented by multiple wildlife conservation stakeholders can help gauge the conservation status of their wildlife resources.

## 1\. Main

In conservation biology, a fundamental objective is to monitor and understand the population dynamics of species, particularly those that are elusive, rare, spatially demanding and charismatic ( [Marsh and Trenham, 2008](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib27)). This endeavour is often complicated by several factors, including financial constraints, the intrinsic difficulty of monitoring elusive species across large landscapes, and a lack of cooperation among agencies and stakeholders ( [Gopalaswamy et al., 2022](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib20)). Uganda's conservation landscape is a prime example of these challenges, facing some of the world's most pressing issues such as rapid human population growth (UN 2022), significant food security concerns ( [Atamanov et al., 2022](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib2)), and severe rates of habitat destruction, notably in its forests ( [Sassen et al., 2013](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib46)). Additionally, the economic impact of human-wildlife conflict in Uganda is substantial, with farmers facing one of the highest financial risks due to livestock predation globally ( [Braczkowski et al., 2023](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib10)), further compounding the urgency for a science-based approach to balance national economic goals with biodiversity conservation.

Charismatic megafauna like gorillas, chimpanzees, and large carnivores are at the heart of Uganda's wildlife tourism sector, an industry pivotal for achieving the country's economic targets, including boosting GDP and reducing national debt. This sector not only contributes significantly to economic development but also serves as a vital mechanism for promoting wildlife conservation. In particular, African lions ( _Panthera leo_), leopards ( _Panthera pardus_), and spotted hyenas ( _Crocuta crocuta_) not only serve as iconic symbols for many of Uganda's protected areas but also play a crucial role in generating conservation revenue through ecotourism and, to a lesser extent, trophy hunting. For example, each lion in the Queen Elizabeth National Park is estimated to contribute USD $14,000 annually to the economy, while leopard sightings in Lake Mburo National Park are believed to bring in a collective USD $40,000 each year ( [Plumptre and Roberts, 2006](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib37), [Braczkowski et al., 2022a](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib11)).

Despite the recognized importance of charismatic megafauna in Uganda's conservation and tourism sectors, the country has faced significant challenges in effectively monitoring its carnivore populations. Over recent decades, these challenges have been exacerbated by threats such as widespread poaching, retaliatory killings by livestock owners, and the environmental impact of industrial activities like oil extraction in key habitats such as Murchison Falls National Park ( [Braczkowski et al., 2020c](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib6), [Mudumba et al., 2021](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib30), [Mudumba et al., 2023](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib31), [Montgomery et al., 2023](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib29)). The scarcity of detailed information on these species' numbers ( [Omoya et al., 2014](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib35), [Braczkowski et al., 2020b](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib9), [Braczkowski et al., 2022a](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib11), [Braczkowski et al., 2022b](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib8)) underscores a wider concern regarding wildlife conservation efforts across Africa, including in Uganda: the complex challenges of monitoring large carnivores due to their expansive ranges and low densities, stakeholder conflicts that impede collaboration and data sharing, competition for limited conservation funding, and the use of unreliable monitoring methodologies ( [Braczkowski et al., 2020a](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib7)). This lack of effective monitoring undermines conservation efforts, leaving crucial questions about the state of these species and the effectiveness of protective measures unanswered.

To confront these challenges, we collaborated with the Uganda Wildlife Authority (UWA) and other stakeholders, conducting training workshops on robust carnivore survey techniques based on Bayesian spatial capture-recapture models. This effort culminated in a comprehensive national survey across six key, protected areas, providing valuable information on the abundance, density, sex ratios, movement scales, and spatial density variations of African lions, leopards, and spotted hyenas. These insights have been instrumental in shaping the new Strategic Action Plan for Large Carnivore Conservation in Uganda (2023–2033), demonstrating the potential of collaborative, science-based conservation strategies to enhance our understanding and protection of Uganda's critical carnivore populations.

## 2\. Methods

### 2.1. Study area

We conducted our surveys in six of Uganda’s most important protected areas for large carnivores in terms of protected area size, and historic presence of carnivores (UWA 2010): the Kidepo Valley National Park (1430 km2), Pian Upe Wildlife Reserve (2400 km2), Murchison Falls National Park (4000 km2), Toro Semliki Wildlife Reserve (542 km2), the Queen Elizabeth Conservation area (comprising the National Park and its associated wildlife reserves 2400 km2), and Lake Mburo National Park (376 km2, [Fig. 1](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#fig0005) – all protected area sizes and shapefiles are available at [www.protectedplanet.net](http://www.protectedplanet.net/)). Except in Pian Upe which has one rainy season, these sites are characterized by two wet seasons (March-May and September-December) with rainfall varying from 800 to 1390 mm per annum. Temperatures range from a minimum of 22 °C to a maximum of 40 °C ( [Twesigye et al., 2022](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib48)). Altitudinal variation across these protected areas is vast and the lowest altitude of ∼700 m above sea level (masl) is located in the Toro Semliki Wildlife Reserve in the country’s west, and the highest points are located in the northeast on the peaks of Mount Morungole in Kidepo Valley National Park, and on Mount Kadam in Pian Upe Wildlife Reserve 2749–3068 masl ( [Aleper and Moe, 2006](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib1); see: [https://ugandawildlife.org/wildlifereserves/pian-upe/](https://ugandawildlife.org/wildlifereserves/pian-upe/)). Due to the wide band of rainfall and altitudes, habitat characteristics are highly variable and are described in detail in [Braczkowski et al. (2020b)](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib9), [Mudumba et al. (2021)](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib30), and [Braczkowski et al. (2022b)](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib8) but each park is characterized by grassland and woodland savanna matrices, with Toro Semliki, Queen Elizabeth, Kidepo Valley, and Murchison containing large tracts of tropical and mountain forest. Key ungulate species important for carnivore persistence include the Cape buffalo _Syncerus caffer_, Uganda kob _Kobus kob thomasi_, impala _Aepyceros melampus_ (present in Lake Mburo only), waterbuck _Kobus ellipsiprymnus_, oribi _Ourebia ourebi_ (Pian Upe, Murchison, and Kidepo), and Burchell’s zebra _Equus quagga burchellii_.

### 2.2. Statement on animal subjects

We received a research permit for our work from the Uganda Wildlife Authority (UWA, permit number COD/96/05). Our work was non-invasive, followed the same rules as safari photography and also made use of remote camera trap photography. We received clearance for all field activities from Mrs. Beth Mutumba (Directorate of Research Management and Quality Assurance) and the Ugandan National Council for Science and Technology (registration number NS331ES).

### 2.3. Estimating abundance and density of large carnivores: field protocols

We established the abundance and density of African lions across the three remaining protected areas where they still occur (Kidepo Valley, Murchison Falls, and the Queen Elizabeth Conservation Area) using individual lion identifications collected using unstructured spatial sampling protocols ( [Elliot and Gopalaswamy, 2017](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib16), [Western et al., 2022](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib51)) which took the form of vehicle-based searches of lions. In the case of African leopards and spotted hyenas, we established densities and abundance by identifying individual animals in photographs recorded across a grid of camera traps deployed at key areas of conservation interest in each protected area, namely the core tourism and management zones (e.g. the Nile Delta of Murchison Falls, and the tourism area of the Pian Upe Wildlife Reserve; see [Fig. 2](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#fig0010) for details). For lions, fieldwork was conducted over roughly three months in Murchison Falls National Park (94 days, 5 Apr-7 Jul 2022), Queen Elizabeth Conservation Area (96 days, 26 Aug-29 Nov 2022), and Kidepo Valley (101 days, 31 Aug – 9 Dec 2022). In each site we used vehicle-based protocols to locate African lions, whereby an observation team systematically covered the study area searching for lions and recording their search effort using smartphones and the open source MapMyDrive ( [Ring, 2017](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib40)) which created GPX files of the kilometers driven daily. Whenever lions were encountered during these searches, the team would photograph each lion, its whisker spots, scars, teeth, and other discernible characteristics ( [Pennycuick and Rudnai, 1970](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib36)). These photographs were taken using DSLR cameras (various models) equipped with telephoto lenses ( [Braczkowski et al., 2020b](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib9)). The photos taken during each lion sighting were added to a parent folder for that sighting, with sub-folders containing all images of each detected individual. An observer then assigned a gender (based on secondary sexual characteristics) and a unique ID (based on their unique whisker spot pattern). An ID catalogue was created for each new individual. For subsequent sightings, if the whisker spots of a detected individual matched an individual in the existing ID catalogue, it was classed as a recapture. If the whisker spots did not match, it was classed as a new individual and a new catalogue was created. For analysis, we only retained individuals that were bilaterally identified at least once during a survey. Finally, we assigned an age class to each individual based on phenotypic features ( [Miller et al., 2016](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib28)), and excluded individuals estimated to be under the age of one year. To help ensure accuracy of the capture histories, each detection was then validated by one other observer. In the Murchison and Kidepo field sites we boosted the detection probability of African lions with playbacks of a buffalo in distress, pig squeals, or a lion roar if we suspected the presence of a male lion in the area. Playback sites were chosen opportunistically, and we followed the protocol of [Western et al. (2022)](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib51) in the duration of playbacks, volume, and rotation of speakers. Critically, for our African lion surveys drive search effort was expended as much as possible across the entirety of the protected areas, however there were some areas we could not explore ( [Fig. 2](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#fig0010), namely the Kidepo valley section of the Kidepo Valley National Park, the Budongo Forest and southeast regions of Murchison Falls, and the Maramagambo and Dura sectors of the Queen Elizabeth Conservation Areas).

For the estimation of leopard and spotted hyena densities, a single season camera-trap survey was conducted in each site (see [Fig. 2](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#fig0010) for camera trap station layout in each site). Survey areas were largely focused on key tourism zones and areas considered critical from a management perspective within each protected area. These included the Nile Delta of Murchison Falls National Park (a poaching and oil extraction hub, and the main tourism area), the tourism and hunting circuit of the Pian Upe Wildlife Reserve (the only part of the protected area with any road access), the Narus valley and OP barracks road along with one access point into the Kidepo Valley portion of Kidepo Valley National Park, the tourism circuits and crater lake areas of Queen Elizabeth, the entirety of Lake Mburo, and the tourism circuit of Toro Semliki. Similar to our lion surveys, camera trapping sessions were short to maintain temporal closure (mean survey period=65.2 days, [Table 1](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#tbl0005)). Camera traps were deployed in pairs (so as to photograph both flanks of a passing carnivore, which improves individual identification), ensuring comprehensive coverage of the target areas (mean number of camera trap locations per survey=39). For leopards we were able to make use of both flanks, but due to the aggregation, scent-marking, and camera tampering behaviour of spotted hyenas it is often impossible to pair two flanks of the same individual hyena to a temporally independent capture event ( [Braczkowski et al., 2022a](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib11), [Dheer et al., 2022](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib13)). For these reasons, for spotted hyenas we used the flank with the highest number of detections. To boost capture probability of leopards and spotted hyenas we placed traps strategically along roads, game trails, and dry riverbeds ( [Balme et al., 2009](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib4), [Henschel et al., 2014](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib23)). Traps were mounted on 1 m steel poles positioned 40 cm above the ground set at a 60°–75° angle relative to a vehicle track or game trail. To meet accepted trap spacing requirements, we considered the smallest known female leopard home-range recorded in the literature, which was approximately 30 km² ( [Bailey, 1993](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib3), [Fattebert et al., 2016](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib17)). As female leopards and spotted hyenas generally have smaller home ranges compared to males, the camera spacing was set to roughly 2 km, ensuring the presence of at least one camera-trap site within an area corresponding to a female leopard’s home range. Even though spatial capture-recapture models do not necessitate it, we made certain that every animal in the survey zone had a nonzero probability of capture, thus ensuring comprehensive coverage of the area ( [Karanth and Nichols, 1998](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib24)). Camera traps were checked roughly every 4–7 days, and opportunistically when field staff traversed the study area. This periodic assessment allowed for necessary adjustments, including rectifying animal-induced damage, replacing memory cards, and ensuring solar panel functionality. To maximize the chances of capturing relevant data, the camera traps were set to burst mode, capturing five consecutive images whenever the infrared sensor was triggered.

### 2.4. Estimating abundance and density of large carnivores: data analysis

Our analyses were all conducted within a Bayesian spatial capture-recapture (SCR) framework. First, we delineated a state-space that would be >2.5 times the expected spatial scale parameter, sigma (σ). Next, we identified potential species activity centers, typically represented by 0.336 km² pixels. However, due to the size of Murchison, for African lions we adjusted the pixel size to 1 km² to expedite computational efficiency. Pixels that were deemed to be unsuitable habitat (e.g. Lake Albert) were masked out. The value of M (the data-augmented value of abundance within the larger state-space) was set at between 10 and 20 times the number of individuals detected during each survey. Following the approach of [Elliot and Gopalaswamy (2017)](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib16) and [Western et al. (2022)](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib51), we described the observation process using a spatial capture-recapture (SCR) matrix, consisting of individuals, sampling occasions, and 'trap' locations. For African lions, we incorporated an effort covariate (logarithm of kilometers driven per trap (0.336 km2 for Kidepo and Queen Elizabeth, and 1 km2 for Murchison), per day) (effort1), and in Murchison and Kidepo a binary variable for our playback protocol (per trap) to mitigate sampling bias in specific traps (effort2). Additionally, sex-specific covariates were included for African lions and leopards to address differences in ranging patterns between males and females, thereby influencing the observation process. By accounting for different detection probabilities for males and females, we also estimated sex ratios. Four a-priori models were developed, and their posterior outputs were compared (see [Table 2](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#tbl0010)), (model 1) _λ_ 0 (basal encounter rate) and σ (the rate of decline in detection probability) were assumed to be sex-specific, (model 2) _λ_ 0 was assumed to be independent of sex, but σ was sex-specific, (model 3) both _λ_ 0 and σ were assumed to be independent of sex, and (model 4) _λ_ 0 was assumed to be sex-specific, but σ was not sex-specific (see Supporting Information 1 for parameter definitions). The detection function parameter (θ) was fixed at 1, indicating a half-normal detection function. All four models were implemented for lions and leopards at all sites. For hyenas, since we were unable to differentiate between sexes, we restricted our analyses to model 3 which does not include sex-specific parameters.

The models were run using an adaptation of the R package SCRbayes ( [Royle et al., 2019](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib43), [Western et al., 2022](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib51)), which implements a Bayesian Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) approach using the Metropolis–Hastings algorithm ( [Tierney, 1994](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib47)). We ran these models typically at 11,000 iterations per chain and set four chains for each model with an initial burn in of 1000 iterations. We assessed convergence using the Gelman–Rubin diagnostic and assumed convergence if the r-hat value was <1.05 for each parameter ( [Gelman and Rubin, 1992](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib18)). If non-convergence persisted, we discarded more initial iterations, or we reran the analysis with more iterations. To select a model to report, we used two steps. First, we performed a goodness-of-fit evaluation, using the Bayesian p-value based on individual encounters ( [Royle et al., 2009](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib42)). We used this tool to reject models whose p-value lay outside the extremities (between 0.15 and 0.85). Second, we visually assessed pair-wise correlation plots of the posterior outputs to assess parameter redundancy. While we reported the Marginal Likelihood estimates, it was difficult to thoroughly examine the Geweke diagnostics to utilize them as an additional tool for model selection, as outlined in ( [Samarasinghe et al., 2022](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib45)). All R scripts, functions, and data for our analysis are available in [Supporting Information 3](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#sec0120).

To estimate abundance, we added site and species-specific buffers around the sampled traps to delineate an effective sample area (ESA). To create this buffer, we calculated the species-specific weighted mean of the estimated movement parameters (σmale, σfemale) and multiplied this by χ0.05,22, which then encompasses an area containing 95 % of all movement outcomes ( [Royle et al., 2013](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib41)). We then calculated the area of each buffer and multiplied it by our species-specific posterior mean density estimates to obtain posterior mean abundance estimates. Where relevant, we also calculated abundance within specific management areas (e.g. the national park) using area multiplied by posterior mean density.

### 2.5. Providing on-the-job training to conservation stakeholders across Uganda

We implemented training workshops in five of the six protected areas where we worked. Potential participants were identified in each landscape using the knowledge of key local stakeholders in each site as determined by the Uganda Wildlife Authority Technical Team on Large Carnivores (an expert group formed at the invitation of the wildlife authority comprised of AB, TM, NE, AR, and AG). Participants were invited to a location at the study landscape of interest (e.g. UWA education center or national park hall), trained in field techniques pertaining to both camera trapping and the search encounter technique ( [Russell et al., 2012](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib44), [Elliot and Gopalaswamy, 2017](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib16)), and provided with DSLR cameras and iPhones loaded with tracking software ( [Ring, 2017](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib40)). Workshops typically lasted 3 days with an intensive “on-the-job survey” exercise where participants were given an opportunity to partake in the field data collection components of either or both the spatial positioning of camera traps for African leopards and spotted hyenas, and the spatial location of African lions using a GPS tracker logging their search effort. Then, they returned to the classroom to analyze the data they collected, identifying individual lions, leopards, and spotted hyenas ( [Pennycuick and Rudnai, 1970](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib36)). These field-based workshops also marked the commencement of our carnivore surveys.

## 3\. Results

For lions, all reported data summaries and estimates are restricted to lions over the estimated age of one year. The highest density of African lions was recorded in Murchison Falls National Park, where average, park-wide densities were 7.43 individuals/100 km2 (Posterior standard deviation (PSD)=1.05, [Fig. 3](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#fig0015) and [Supporting Information 1](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#sec0120)), with local densities being highest in the Nile Delta (16 individuals/100 km2) and declining sharply across the remainder of the park. In Queen Elizabeth National Park, our 2022 survey revealed a density of 1.64 lions/100 km2 (PSD=0.33). In Kidepo Valley National Park densities of lions were some of the lowest recorded in Africa (0.87 individuals/100 km2, PSD=0.46).
