### 3.1. Kidepo Valley National Park

The cumulative search effort was 4519 km for African lions and 1262 trap nights from 60 paired camera trap locations for leopards and hyenas ( [Table 1](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#tbl0005)). We identified five unique lions (3 males, 2 females), nine leopards (4 males, 5 females), and 43 spotted hyenas (sex not noted) during our surveys. Our lion estimate in Kidepo is the lowest in Uganda (0.87 lions/100 km2), with an abundance of 12.44 (PSD=6.53) individuals in the national park, and 22.23 (PSD=11.67) in the 2555 km2 ESA, which includes community lands around the park ( [Fig. 3](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#fig0015)). Leopard densities were 6.26 individuals/100 km2 (PSD=2.30) and abundance within the 432 km2 ESA was 27.04 leopards (PSD=9.96). Spotted hyena density was estimated at 29.71 individuals/100 km2 (PSD=6.11), which amounts to 125.68 hyenas (PSD=25.83) in 423 km2 ( [Supporting Information 1](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#sec0120)).

### 3.2. Pian Upe Wildlife Reserve

The survey effort was 858 trap nights from 28 paired camera trap locations surveying leopards and hyenas ( [Table 1](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#tbl0005)). No lion surveys were conducted, as the species is locally extinct. We identified 14 leopards (5 males, 9 females), and 39 spotted hyenas. African leopard densities were the lowest in the Pian Upe Wildlife Reserve at 1.60 individuals/100 km2 (PSD=0.49) and abundance in the 1357 km2 ESA was 21.65 leopards (PSD=6.60). Spotted hyenas occurred at a density of 16.13 individuals/100 km2 (PSD=4.50) and an abundance of 151.47 hyenas in a 939 km2 area (PSD=42.29), the fourth largest density recorded in the country ( [Supporting Information 1](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#sec0120)).

### 3.3. Murchison Falls National Park

The cumulative search effort was 13442 km for African lions, and 1603 trap nights from 32 paired camera trap locations for leopards and hyenas ( [Table 1](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#tbl0005)). We identified 57 unique lions (19 males, 38 females), 27 leopards (10 males, 17 females), and 83 spotted hyenas. Murchison Falls National Park had the highest density and abundance for all three species in our assessment. Lion densities were 7.43 individuals/100 km2 (PSD=1.05), with the highest densities nearing 16 individuals/100 km2 in the Nile Delta – the park’s high tourism region ( [Fig. 3](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#fig0015)). Abundance was 240 (PSD=34) lions in a 3233 km2 area. Similarly, both the densities of African leopards (14.06 individuals/100 km2, PSD=2.65), and spotted hyenas (45.31 individuals/100 km2, PSD=5.42) reached their highest densities in the Nile Delta and were the highest in Uganda during our study. Leopard abundance in a 262 km2 area in the Nile Delta was 36.83 individuals (PSD=6.95). Spotted hyena abundance within the ESA (355 km2) was 160.86 individuals (PSD=19.23). See [Supporting Information 1](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#sec0120) for detailed spatial densities across the ESAs.

### 3.4. Toro Semliki Wildlife Reserve

Despite surveying for a total 407 trap nights from 25 paired camera trap stations, we failed to detect any lions, leopards, or spotted hyenas in the Toro Semliki Wildlife Reserve.

### 3.5. Queen Elizabeth Conservation Area

The cumulative search effort was 8358 km for African lions, and 1513 trap nights from 55 paired camera trap locations for leopards and hyenas ( [Table 1](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#tbl0005)). We identified 19 unique lions (10 males, 9 females) across the survey area. In the northern Mweya survey (which extended into Kasenyi and the craters) we identified 15 individual spotted hyenas. We could not estimate leopard density in the northern survey due to very low sample size. In the southern Ishasha survey we identified seven leopards (2 males, 4 females, 1 individual sex not distinguishable) and 63 spotted hyenas. We recorded a density of 1.64 lions/100 km2 (PSD=0.33) and an abundance of 39.34 (PSD=7.96) in the 2400 km2 Queen Elizabeth Conservation Area ( [Fig. 3](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#fig0015)). African leopard density in the Ishasha sector of Queen Elizabeth was 1.48 individuals/100 km2 (PSD=0.57) and the abundance in 805 km2 was 11.91 individuals (PSD=3.83). Spotted hyena density in the northern survey was 34.28 individuals (PSD=9.09) while in the Ishasha survey this was 22.07 individuals/100 km2 (PSD=3.73). Spotted hyena abundance in the 219 km2 area of Kasenyi in the north of the park was 75.06 spotted hyenas (PSD=19.91) and in the 386.4 km2 Ishasha sampling area we estimated 86.18 hyenas (PSD=14.40).

### 3.6. Lake Mburo National Park

The cumulative search effort was 1377 trap nights from 32 paired camera trap locations for leopards and hyenas ( [Table 1](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#tbl0005)). No lion surveys were conducted, as the species is locally extinct. We identified 25 leopards (7 males, 15 females, 2 individuals where sex was not distinguishable), and 25 spotted hyenas during our surveys. African leopard density was 11.58 individuals/100 km2 (PSD=2.46, [Fig. 3](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#fig0015)) and abundance was 42.85 individuals in 370 km2 (PSD=9.12, [Supporting Information 1](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#sec0120)). Spotted hyena density was 6.15 individuals/100 km2 (PSD=1.42) and abundance was 22.76 individuals in the park (PSD=5.26).

## 4\. Discussion

### 4.1. The status of Uganda’s large carnivore populations

#### 4.1.1. African Lions

Our results shine an important light on the plight of Uganda’s large carnivore guild, a critical ecotourism drawcard, across its protected area network. The most important result from our survey is the very low density and abundance estimate of African lions in the Kidepo Valley ecosystem, and the Queen Elizabeth Conservation Area. These populations appear to be dangerously close to local extirpation. In Kidepo, we observed most lion sightings near the park headquarters, a classic case of protection only in close proximity to an authority. In 2009, a call-up survey was conducted in Kidepo ( [Omoya et al., 2014](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib35)). A total of 24 call-ups were conducted and resulted in 28 lion detections. The authors estimated their survey sampled an area of 183 km2 (13 % of the National Park) and extrapolated their estimates to the whole park to provide an estimate of 130 lions across the national park ( [Omoya et al., 2014](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib35)). While this extrapolation may have resulted in an inflated population estimate, our survey does suggest a marked decline in the intervening years. Despite a considerable increase in effort (4500 km of search effort, and 41 playbacks), we recorded fewer detections (16) of just five individuals. Anecdotal evidences collected during and immediately after the Kidepo survey suggests that deliberate poaching of African lions may be the key threat to this population, as at least six killed lions were retrieved from poachers or their traps in a period of a few months (UWA unpublished data).

Similarly, in the Queen Elizabeth Conservation Area we observed a near 50 % decline in lion density and abundance from the 2018 survey of [Braczkowski et al. (2020b)](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib9). The reason for this sharp decline is probably because of decreasing number of lionesses in the population, affecting not only the recruitment of cubs, but also accelerating infanticide events. Evidence from the Kasenyi plains of the park shows at least five infanticide events have occurred in the past four years (Uganda Carnivore Program, unpublished data), sex ratios are inverted when compared to healthy source populations at 1 female: 2 males ( [Braczkowski et al., 2020b](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib9)), and female pride size is small (x=2.1 females). This offtake of females is a result of repeated poisoning events by cattle farmers and poachers (e.g. six lions poisoned in Ishasha sector on March 17 2021, [Kigongo, 2022](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib26)) and stochastic events like electrocution ( [Musoke, 2022](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib33)). This decline in African lions is contrasted by the rise of spotted hyena densities in both the northern and southern parts of the park, which appear to have increased significantly concomitant to the lion decline (the density in Mweya has doubled while in Ishasha it has risen by ∼30 %, [Braczkowski et al., 2022b](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib8)). Whether this increase is owed to the decline of lions is difficult to ascertain.

A critical positive from our surveys is that the Uganda Wildlife Authority and the efforts of several NGOs (e.g. Uganda Conservation Foundation, Snares to Wares) in snare removal appear to be effective in the Nile Delta region of Murchison Falls National Park, whilst also recognizing the natural productivity of this habitat. Our estimate of 240 lions in 4059 km2 (excluding the Budongo forest and southeastern portion of the park) suggests this population still occurs at high densities in localized parts of the park, especially in the Nile Delta where densities reach nearly 16 individuals/100 km2, some of the highest in unfenced systems in Africa (see [Elliot et al., 2021](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib14), for rigorous estimates of lion densities in Kenya for comparison). This is notable as Murchison experiences high snare pressure ( [Mudumba et al., 2021](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib30)), but with intensive anti-poaching efforts still manages to maintain an estimated 246 Uganda kob /km2 in areas of the park (Mudumba et al. in review).

### 4.2. African leopards

Our camera trap surveys of leopards in key tourism areas of Uganda show that leopards still exist at high densities in two national parks (Murchison Falls and Lake Mburo), and at mid-tier densities – for African savanna populations – in one more site, Kidepo. One reason for the high densities at Murchison Falls and Lake Mburo is the high densities of important prey species; Uganda kob (Mudumba et al. in review) in the former and impala in the latter ( [Braczkowski et al., 2022a](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib11)). Conversely, the low leopard density in Pian Upe is likely due to the very low density of medium-sized preferred prey in the reserve, which unlike larger prey (e.g. roan, waterbuck, buffalo, and hartebeest) – have not managed to recover from historic poaching in the past. Our camera trap data detected only low numbers of oribi in the region immediately around the Karamoja Overland Safaris base camp, and in the eastern part of the reserve near Mukalazi army barracks (see [Zwick et al., 1998](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib52) report on the extremely low densities of wildlife in the region during the 1996–1997 surveys). This contrasts with the much higher densities of larger prey we observed, and also the high hyena density (16.13 hyenas/100 km2) in the region.

### 4.3. Spotted hyenas

Our spotted hyena density estimates show that the species is still widespread in Uganda’s national parks and occurs at densities roughly 8–40 times those of African lions. The majority of the densities we present here (except for Lake Mburo) are also higher than estimates from surveys using the same robust methods (i.e. SECR-based studies) in Mkhuze Game Reserve in South Africa (10.6/100 km2, [De Blocq, 2014](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib12)), and Tuli Block (14.9 hyenas/100 km2, Vissia et al., 2021), Ghanzi (2.3/100 km2, [Kent and Hill, 2013](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib25)) and Ngamiland (10.1/100 km2, [Rich et al., 2019](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib39)) in Botswana. These results are likely reflective of two phenomena: 1) spotted hyenas are more resilient than lions to wire snare poaching (Becker et al., 2023), the causes of lion decline in Uganda, and 2) their large clan sizes allow them to hunt larger prey items, such as buffalo. Our results mirror those of [Henschel et al. (2010)](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib22), whose multi-site assessment of African lions in West Africa showed that in many of the areas where lions were extirpated, spotted hyenas continued to persist.

### 4.4. The importance of teamwork in achieving a national survey of Uganda’s large carnivores

Our study and collaborative effort was conducted on a smaller scale than the large carnivore surveys recently conducted in Kenya, which brought together > 400 people from more than 40 organizations ( [Elliot et al., 2021](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib14), [Ngene et al., 2023](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib34)). That initiative estimated density and abundance of African lions in ten key source populations and occupancy of six large carnivores throughout Kenya. Our survey also drew an important lesson from the Kenyan effort: working closely with the Ugandan government and actively involving their staff in the data collection effort, setting up a bottom-up, three-pronged approach when designing this carnivore survey, whereby 1) a protected area of interest was identified by the technical team, 2) critical stakeholders in the landscape of interest were identified and invited to participate in a statistical and field skill workshop, and 3) these stakeholders were invited to participate in the survey. This approach facilitated the inclusion of over 100 conservation stakeholders ( _inter alia_ government rangers, local university students, independent scientists, and trophy hunters) in the survey with varying levels of involvement ( [Table 4](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#tbl0020)). Many of these stakeholders had not had previous opportunity to participate in a wildlife survey, and some had not even been to a protected area. Equally important, our survey spread the cost burden of fieldwork across different entities. Our study therefore provides another important example of the power of collaboration in surveying charismatic species over large landscapes (e.g. wolves in Italy, bears in Alberta, lions in Kenya, giraffe and zebra in Kenya, [Bischof et al., 2020](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib5)).

Finally, the political situation regarding carnivore conservation in Uganda is particularly negative with NGOs, scientists, and donors in regular conflict over the rights to work on the remaining populations (mainly of lions), rights to collar individual animals, and data openness. Inclusion of multiple conservation stakeholders in a country-wide survey of carnivores facilitated agreement on the sites selected, analysis, and veracity of their population densities and abundance, and potentially set the ground for broader conservation stakeholder collaborations in the future. What is now needed is to follow up with the stakeholders that were included in the survey attempt in gauging if they thought the collaborative exercise was useful in calming some of these issues, whether participants saw benefit in working on the survey, and if they had any negative experiences.

### 4.5. Study limitations

A key limitation of our initiative was the inference we could draw for our African leopard and spotted hyena surveys. Our density estimates and resulting abundance values only extended to the ESA around our camera trapping areas. This represents a best-case scenario for these species in these landscapes and we recommend wider surveys in places like Murchison, Pian Upe, Kidepo, and Queen Elizabeth, where both species occur beyond the bounds of the sampling areas covering the highly traversed tourism areas in our study. Critically, we do not extend our inference beyond ESA buffer as densities will change sharply based on habitat type, topography, and prey availability. While our study encompassed significant protected areas on a national scale, it suggests that intensifying survey efforts could yield improvements in the coefficient of variation of our estimates, inviting comparisons with the more favorable CVs reported by [Elliot et al. (2021)](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib14). We also note that during our lion surveys, large sections of Murchison and Kidepo were inaccessible owing to insecurity, a lack of roads and restricted possibilities for off-road driving. This limited our ability to sample throughout these parks, and additionally, logistical challenges led to infrequent sampling in more remote areas. As a result, our ESA boundaries for these areas, while ecologically meaningful and statistically grounded, do include large unsampled areas with large uncertainty. Future surveys in these parks should aim to overcome these challenges and sample more widely and uniformly to corroborate our estimates. Indeed, uniform and comprehensive coverage of an area of interest is a goal that all such surveys should strive for.

### 4.6. Conservation and policy implications

African lions are functionally extinct in at least three Ugandan protected areas (Toro Semliki Wildlife Reserve, Pian Upe Wildlife Reserve, and Lake Mburo National Park). They now persist in only three parks, two of which already have critically low numbers, especially for females, which jeopardizes the reproductive potential of these populations. The near 50 % decline of Uganda’s most iconic population – the Tree Climbing Lions of Queen Elizabeth – should herald a call for long-term commitments of conservation action that has a clear goal of population recovery, rather than conserving the status quo. Lions across Uganda are facing a snaring crisis with their populations under immense pressure ( [Braczkowski et al., 2020b](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib9), [Montgomery et al., 2023](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib29)), and this is again highlighted in Kidepo where the use of wheel traps and snaring has led to a near extinction of lions in the system. Another critical finding of the survey results was the value that monitoring brings to tracking population changes in key areas – there is a clear need for a robust, repeatable, monitoring framework across the country. Without such a strategy we would have never established the dire nature of both the Kidepo and Queen Elizabeth lion populations. In fact, the Kidepo survey revealed a disparity of perceived lion numbers by field staff (∼100 individuals, Uganda Wildlife Authority Kidepo field ranger unit, pers.comm) to the reality on the ground of just 12 individuals in the national park. These habitat environments in both Kidepo and Queen Elizabeth lend themselves to naturally high detection probability (large granite kopjes, and a cultural behavior of tree-climbing in lion populations). When a tourist, scientist, or ranger observes a lion in these areas it is unforgettable and iconic. Consequently, high detection rates of the same individual lions and a lack of data over prolonged periods of time can lure field staff and tourists into complacency that densities are high and conservation action is working. Using robust methods, we here tease apart these intertwined detection and ecological processes from one another.

Finally, these results were at the center of a critical African lion recovery dialogue held in Entebbe on May 7th 2024 (with several prominent government and policymakers present, [Muganga, 2024](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib32)). Local and international media gave significant attention to these findings, including a prominent news agency in India ( [Upadhyay, 2024](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib49)), which compared Uganda’s lion situation to India’s only remaining population of lions in Gujarat which is believed to be increasing in population size ( [Ram et al., 2023](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib38)). The report even suggested that Uganda could consider adopting Gujarat’s model of lion conservation. It should be noted, however, that India’s claims of rising lion numbers are based on an index-based methodology referred to as ‘minimal total count by direct beat verification’ ( [Ram et al., 2023](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib38)). Like many index-based surveys, this method does not explicitly account for detection probability. As a result, estimates of abundance and trends can be significantly influenced by variations in detection probability (see [Gopalaswamy et al., 2015](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib21), for a detailed mathematical explanation of this concept; [DrÖge et al. (2020)](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib15), for an assessment of its inefficiency in estimating lion population size; and [Gogoi et al. (2020)](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib19), which reports a much lower lion density compared to the estimate provided by [Ram et al. (2023)](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235198942400516X#bib38), for the Gir Protected Area in Gujarat, India).

## What is Wildlife Tracking and Monitoring?

Wildlife monitoring is essential for keeping track of animal movement patterns, habitat utilisation, population demographics, snaring and poaching incidents and breakouts. This valuable information, which Wildlife ACT and our conservation volunteers gather on our wildlife volunteer projects, has numerous management applications, including the planning of successful introduction and removal strategies of Africa’s wildlife.

## Wildlife ACT’s Wildlife Monitoring Service

Many African game reserves do not have the funds or capacity to run effective [wildlife monitoring projects](https://www.wildlifeact.com/volunteer) despite monitoring being an essential part of conservation. Wildlife ACT assists these game reserves by providing tracking and monitoring services free of charge.

Wildlife ACT is unique in that we actively advance conservation by initiating, implementing and managing monitoring projects on reserves which do not have existing monitoring programmes in place; or by taking over existing monitoring projects on reserves that can no longer fund or manage them.

## Why Volunteers are Needed for Wildlife Tracking and Monitoring?

As a conservation volunteer, you play a vital role by assisting Wildlife ACT’s research monitors on our wildlife volunteer projects. You will be the monitor’s direct assistant and aid them with their daily activities. You will experience what it’s like to be one of Africa’s wildlife researchers. This will give you the opportunity to learn not only about these focal endangered species but also about many other aspects of the African bush-veld; and gain exclusive hands-on experience.

## Daily Activities as a Wildlife Conservation Volunteer

Daily activities on our wildlife volunteer projects include wildlife tracking and monitoring of endangered species, which include the African wild dog, cheetah, black rhino and vulture. Monitoring of elephant, buffalo, lion, hyena, leopard and white rhino will also take place on a more ad hoc basis. To effectively conserve endangered species, we also need to understand how they are impacted by priority species with high ecological impacts. These priority species include elephant, hyena, lion, leopard, white rhino and buffalo.

## What is Wildlife Monitoring?

- Using radio telemetry or identifying tracks, you’ll begin locating an animal. Once you’ve found the animal, various important data is recorded, such as the GPS location, group composition, associations and behaviour.
- The next step is to photograph the animal. These photographic recordings are used in the development of an accurate identikit for identifying specific individuals. These activities are most often conducted from a 4×4 vehicle – driven by the Wildlife ACT monitor and take place during early mornings and late evenings – with a midday break taken in between monitoring sessions.
- An essential task for our monitoring teams is keeping Identikits up to date. These allow us to identify individual animals via information and quality photographs that profile the animal for accurate identification in the field. So during wildlife tracking sessions, being equipped and at the ready to take quality photos of endangered & priority species from all angles is very much a part of the job!
- Your ‘break’ is usually filled-up carrying out your camp maintenance and cleaning and cooking responsibilities.
- As a conservation volunteer, it is part of your responsibility to help run our camps in order to keep them well-maintained and clean. As such, you will be assigned certain responsibilities that will assist the monitor in running each camp.

## Occasional Activities:

Depending on how long you stay with us and what time of the year it is, you might also get the opportunity to experience:

- Wildlife tracking and radio collaring of animals;
- Relocation and re-introduction of game;
- Rescuing animals caught in poachers’ snares;
- Identity tagging of animals;
- Night excursions to monitor nocturnal animals such as hyena;
- Vulture counts and nest surveys;
- Bird ringing; or
- Alien plant control

## Anyone can Join as a Wildlife Conservation Volunteer!

If you’d like to join Wildlife ACT as a conservation volunteer you don’t need any special skills or qualifications as all the training will be conducted by our qualified wildlife monitors. All you need is the right attitude and a willingness to help and learn.

We’re looking for conservation volunteers to join our wildlife volunteer projects who want to experience what’s it’s like to be a true conservationist in Africa and contribute to the exciting and important wildlife conservation work we do.
